label[for='src-debug']->title: Orange: above ascent (try to not have pixels peek out here)
Red: main glyph (above baseline, below ascent);
Blue: main glyph (below baseline, above descent);
Aqua: below descent (try to not have pixels peek out here)
P[raw-loc='help-itch']->innerHTML: for changelog, donations, discussions, and an offline version!
P[raw-loc='help-hello']->innerHTML: This tool takes a pixel font as an image and makes an actual TTF file out of it!
UL[raw-loc='help-workflow-list']->innerH: <li>
Draw your font in your preferred editor.
Characters should be aligned to the left edge of a grid
(with or without spacing) - see the example font for reference.
Note: the grid should be consistent-sized, as if you were drawing a tileset.
Import your font via "Open image" button on the top,
by dragging and dropping, or even pasting the image.
Write out the characters you've drawn in "glyphs in image" field
and configure the rest of Input fields to match your image.
Check out mouseover descriptions for notes!
Edit the few Output parameters if you need specific line height.
Edit font information on the Meta tab.
Click "Save TTF" to save your font!
(optional) Use FontForge
if you need to tweak additional settings/metadata.
P[raw-loc='help-supported']->innerHTML: Recent versions of Chrome[-ium], Firefox, and Microsoft Edge.
UL[raw-loc='help-notes-list']->innerHTML: If (lineGap + ascent - descent != EmSize), default line height is implementation-defined
(e.g. Firefox may use EmSize while Chromium uses LG+ASC-DESC)
P[raw-loc='help-privacy']->innerHTML: It is actually your browser that's generating the font!
Google Analytics are used to tell whether anyone is using the tool,
provided that you don't have the browser and/or extensions blocking that.
DIV[raw-loc='import-json']->innerHTML: You can import/export your settings as JSON! Good for revising a font later!
DIV[raw-loc='conf-batch']->innerHTML: Takes pairs of images+JSON files and outputs a ZIP of font files.
#glyph-color->title: Determines criteria for a pixel to be 'visible'
#glyph-width->title: Width of an individual tile containing a glyph
#glyph-height->title: Height of an individual tile containing a glyph
#glyph-ofs-x->title: X offset till the top-left tile
#glyph-ofs-y->title: Y offset till the top-left tile
#glyph-base-x->title: Set this to number of pixels between a tile's left edge and a letter's left edge.
Unless you want letters to be able to overlap adjacent letters on the left, leave as 0 and adjust Offset X instead.
#glyph-baseline->title: Set this to number of pixels between a tile's top edge and bottom of 'tail-less' letters (o, m, c, etc.)
#glyph-spacing->title: In proportional mode, this is the spacing between characters.
In monospace mode, it's a value to add/subtract from your tile width.
If you want to change the width of the 'space' character, add some pixels to it (they will not be visible)
#font-em-square->title: You would usually keep this at a power-of-two and change pixel size instead.
#font-line-gap->title: Line gap is honoured so inconsistently that people argue if it should even be set to non-zero.
#font-ascend->title: Ascent defines how far your letters will usually stretch upwards from baseline.
#font-descend->title: Descent defines how far your letters will usually dip under the baseline.
It's negative because it goes below the baseline, yes.
#font-px-size->title: Power-of-two values (16, 32, 64, 128, etc.) are preferred for making it easier to find the right size (e.g. 16px/12pt for size of 64)
#font-dino->title: A dinosaur to fill an empty spot
#font-version->title: There are no restrictions on what version text can be.
#font-desc->title: Generally shown in file properties on the metadata table.
#font-license->title: Generally shown in file properties on the metadata table.
#font-license-url->title: Not shown as often as you may like.
#in-kerning->placeholder: to reduce spacing between T and o/a by 1 pixel
